events.name: The Inaugural GTUG Toronto Meeting!
events.description:
Come out and meet the gang! This inaugural event marks the first of many action pact events brought to you by the Google Technology Users Group.

The evening will be an extremely casual meet and great. Get some free swag from Google and talk a bit about your favorite Google Technology or what you might want to see in the next GTUG meeting. Help us build the best GTUG north of Silicon Valley!

events.name: March 8th Meeting: Mobile & Android Development
events.description:
Thanks to everyone for making our inaugural Toronto-GTUG meeting so successful! The date and location have been confirmed for our next event, please mark your calendar and join us on March 8th from 6-8pm at the Imperial Pub, Downstairs Room. The meeting will bring together two industry leaders to speak about both mobile and Android development. events.name: Toronto-GTUG May 11th Meeting
events.description:
Calling all Google technology enthusiasts!! We are excited to announce our next Toronto-GTUG event - this time we are meeting in North Toronto. The evening will be a casual meet & greet located at the Frog & Firkin (near Yonge & Sheppard).

where these tools can be found tips on how to effectively use them case studies detailing how they helped save the day scenarios where these tools allowed a functionality or feature that would have otherwise not been possible how these tools were able to help save time We are looking for one more presenter for the 1:45 to 2:15 time slot. events.name: The Toronto GTUG Year-Ender
events.description:
The holidays are upon us and a new year is right around the corner. With the hustle and bustle of the season, sometimes it's nice to kick back, relax, hang out, and just chat. To end off the year, we're going to do just that at the Toronto GTUG.

This time around we'll discuss the plans we have for GTUG over the next year, and we want to hear from you want kind of things you'll be interested to hear/talk about! So come down Thursday night for a fun little get together with the rest of the Toronto GTUG community! And of course, we'll talk some Google while we're at it!

+Mark Reale, @markreale

events.name: Developing for Google TV
events.description:
*******REGISTRATION IS NOW CLOSED*******

*******Waiting list is available.*******

Are you passionate about creating cool apps for a new generation of TVs?

Do you want to be a part of an entertainment revolution that's hitting living rooms in the very near future?

Awesome - because on March 7th you'll get a chance to learn all about it.

Google has invited us down to their offices here in Toronto to teach us all about Google TV and how you can make inspiring, exciting, next-gen applications for their Android-based operating system for televisions.

GTUG members will be given an overview of Google TV and UX design patterns for TV.

Word on the street is that there will also be Pizza, soft drinks and some beer.

And the tantalizingly ambiguous: "There may be a surprise or two."

The Evening's Presenters

Paul Carff

http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/b/3/b/c/event_98146012.jpeg Paul is a Developer Advocate for the Google TV Platform, and is currently engaging with partners to develop applications and Video Sitemaps (improving Video search and discovery). At Google, he has managed a number of internal technical support teams, the Google Analytics Support, and developed data warehousing solutions enabling Google's Sales and Support teams to scale. Before working at Google, Paul was a career Naval Officer working his way from the enlisted to the officer ranks.

Specialties: Video Sitemaps, Google TV

Full profile

 

Les Vogel

http://photos2.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/b/3/f/8/event_98146072.jpeg Les is a Developer Programs Engineer for Google TV. He works closely with Google TV developers, writing sample code and helping them understand how to bring rich, compelling apps to the Google TV Android marketplace. As an eclectic developer, Les has worked on at all levels including hardware drivers, neural networks, accounting and databases for small businesses, solar energy systems, spreadsheets, image processing, electrical power systems monitoring and very smart websites. He's found that making things fast is an exponential benefit for users - faster things often have greater battery life and it tends to delight users, even if they don't understand why. Visible projects: AirPort wireless networking, helped drive the Core99 chipset through the Apple product line; the Newton printed handwriting recognizer; Full Impact spreadsheet engine for Ashton Tate; distributed multi-processor OS for Motorola (Computer cX); a flood management telemetry system and monitoring of solar housing for the TVA; a fail-safe system for Boeing Energy Systems.

Specialties: Google TV for Android

Full Profile

 

Although we'd love for everyone to come, limited spots are available.

NOTE: Attendees will need to sign an NDA for entry into the building to check out this GTUG session

----------------------------------------------------

If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to ask any of us organizers. We're here to help! Give us a shout on Google+ or Twitter!

+Mark Reale, @markreale
+Martin Bryk, @martinbryk
+Anuj Ahooja, @anujahooja

events.name: Fragments: The New Android Building Block [Android Workshop]
events.description:
REGISTRATION FOR THIS EVENT BEGINS ON MARCH 31st, 2012 at 2PM.

As Android 3.x was released and Android tablets began to enter the ecosystem, Google included some more tools in the Android framework as to make it easier to build apps for multiple screen sizes. One of these new tools were Fragments - a new Android building block that sits next to Activities, Services, and all the other basic needs of every application.

With 3.x+ devices out, Fragments are now one of the most important parts of your Android development experience. Knowing this tool inside out will make it significantly easier for you to build apps that scale on different kinds of devices.

So if you've been making Android applications and want to learn how to make apps that work great in the new framework, come down to the GTUG Fragments Workshop!

This workshop will be run by Anuj Ahooja, an Android developer who has meddled with both phones and tablets for the past year and a half and has learned the ins and outs of Android development whether it be 2.x, 3.x, or 4.x.

 

PREREQUISITES:

Have a good understanding of Android development - it will be assumed that you can make a basic Android application very quickly. This is vital as we'll be moving really fast through basic Android concepts and you don't have a good hold of it, you'll fall behind and lose out. Eclipse + Android SDK 3.x+ (get 4.x+ for fake bonus points). Passion to learn, discuss, and share development knowledge.  

IMPORTANT NOTE: There is very limited space for this workshop, so unless you're 95% sure that you're coming, please don't sign up. If you do sign up and decide not to come, please remove your name immediately. If you fail to do so and don't show up to the workshop, you may be banned from further Toronto GTUG events. We want to give everyone a fair chance at learning and we don't want to waste spots as these workshops are in high demand.

 

CONTACT:

If you have any questions, feel free to contact any of the organizers:
+Mark Reale, @markreale
+Martin Bryk, @martinbryk
+Anuj Ahooja, @anujahooja

Emir Hasanbegovic is an Agile Engineer for Xtreme Labs, where he has been a key player in designing the core infrastructure that lines most of Xtreme Labs' Android and Google TV applications. These development tools are what allow for better end user experiences that people have come to expect from the work that Xtreme Labs produces. He shines when working with Xtreme's clients by helping them leverage Mobile Technology to its full potential in an effective and innovative way.

events.name: Javascript Workshop Series pt 1 - Intro to Javascript and jQuery
events.description:
A couple of news items to mention here, folks:

By popular demand, we are resurrecting Meetup.com for use at our GDG meetups.

Seems this is still the way to go for co-ordinating on-going meetups -

We will use the Google+ page for blasting out some news and information, but will look to host details about our on-going meetups here once again.

Second: in collaboration with GDG Waterloo, and in anticipation of the jQueryTO Conference coming up on March 15, we will be hosting a series of 4 Javascript workshops covering the basic fundamentals of Javascript, through to working with APIs, using the popular Angular.js framework, and optimizing your site or web app's performance.

These workshops will culminate in a larger hack event on Saturday, March 8, the weekend before the Conference, bringing together both the GDG Waterloo and GDG Toronto organizations.

This will be our Session 1 - Intro to Javascript and jQuery

We will be covering:

An introduction to Javascript as the core programming language of the web, able to add such things as interactivity and animation to web pages, as well as retrieve and parse information to be displayed to a user.

The journey will start with a review of how Javascript implements the core concepts of a programming language by walking participants through a series of examples.

From there, participants will move toward developing an understanding of how, why and when to use a Javascript library, with jQuery as the example.

Outcomes

By the end of the Workshop, participants will be familiar with core programming concepts as they are implemented with Javascript, and the ability to access the DOM with jQuery.

Prerequisites

Participants should have a basic familiarity of HTML and CSS.

Software Required

• Code editor

• Web browser

Hardware Required

A computer / laptop able to run a modern web browser (Chrome, Firefox, Opera, Safari, IE9+), and a code editor (ie. Sublime, Notepad++, Dreamweaver, etc).

events.name: Javascript Workshop Series pt 2 - Working with Data in Javascript
events.description:
This is Workshop #2 in our series of 4 workshops in collaboration with GDG Waterloo in anticipation of the jQueryTO Conference.

Working with Data in Javascript

Participants will be introduced to APIs and how Javascript can be used to access APIs, retrieve data, manipulate data, and then display the data in the browser in an efficient way.

Outcomes

By the end of the Workshop, participants will have accessed an API, and delivered information back to the browser based on the status of the API request, and the data returned.

Prerequisites

Participants should have a basic familiarity of HTML and CSS, and some Javascript.

Software Required

• Code editor

• Web browser

Hardware Required

A computer / laptop able to run a modern web browser (Chrome, Firefox, Opera, Safari, IE9+), and a code editor (ie. Sublime, Notepad++, Dreamweaver, etc).

events.name: Javascript Workshop Series pt 3 - Mobile Performance Optimization
events.description:
This is Workshop #3 in our series of 4 workshops in collaboration with GDG Waterloo in anticipation of the jQueryTO Conference.

Javascript: Performance Optimization

Participants will be introduced to various techniques related to improving the performance of Javascript-based web applications within the realm of Javascript and related CSS techniques.

Outcomes

By the end of the Workshop, participants will have taken a working web application example, observed performance failures in it, and go through a series of exercises to improve the performance.

Prerequisites

Participants should have a basic familiarity of HTML, CSS and Javascript.

Software Required

• Code editor

• Web browser

Hardware Required

A computer / laptop able to run a modern web browser (Chrome, Firefox, Opera, Safari, IE9+), and a code editor (ie. Sublime, Notepad++, Dreamweaver, etc).

events.name: Javascript Workshop Series pt 4 - Javascript Frameworks: Intro to Angular.js
events.description:
This is Workshop #4 in our series of 4 workshops in collaboration with GDG Waterloo in anticipation of the jQueryTO Conference.

Javascript Frameworks: Intro to Angular.js

Participants will be introduced to the concept of using Javascript Frameworks to take the popular approach to building ‘Single-Page’ Web Applications.

Participants will also review many of the common features of popular frameworks.

Outcomes

By the end of the Workshop, participants will have built a basic Single-Page Web Application using Angular.js.

Prerequisites

Participants should have a basic familiarity of HTML and CSS and Javascript.

Software Required

• Code editor

• Web browser

Hardware Required

A computer / laptop able to run a modern web browser (Chrome, Firefox, Opera, Safari, IE9+), and a code editor (ie. Sublime, Notepad++, Dreamweaver, etc).

events.name: Javascript Hack Night
events.description:
Gearing up for the jQueryTO Conference on March 15:

After our 4 Javascript Workshops over the past month in collaboration with the GDG Waterloo group, we are bringing it all home with a mini Javascript Hackathon Night on Saturday, March 8 at 5pm.

This will give everybody an opportunity to flex their muscle on some Javascript problems and show off some of the new skills and insights that they have developed.

Attendance to the previous sessions are not required, but these previous sessions will form the foundation of the challenges we will have available to attempt.

We will also be doing a raffle for a free pass to the jQueryTO Conference during the session!

Worthy of note:

There will be some very beginner-friendly types of challenges in case you are just learning Javascript.

The evening will get started with a short introduction at 5pm where we will introduce the challenges available to tackle, and then we will dive in and get coding.

Challenges will be based on the following areas:

• Using Javascript to create interesting interactive effects

• Creating 'Javascript Art'

• Building something interesting with data from a handful of selected APIs

• Creating a small Web Application

events.name: July Meetup: Google I/O Recap and Introduction to Dart
events.description:
Hello Everyone!

Calling all Toronto developers to join our upcoming July gathering.

As a follow up to this year's Google I/O Conference, we have a couple of amazing items to discuss in the July Meetup.

We will go over the highlights of Google I/O including:

• Polymer

• New Material Design Documents

• New Google Cardboard

• ATAP Projects

We have invited Faisal Abid, a Google Developer Expert in Dart to share his experiences working with Dart as a server side language.

Date & Time:

Tuesday, July 14 at 7:00 pm

Location:

BNOTIONS Headquarters

Please visit the following google map link for location details: https://goo.gl/maps/CKyIo

Details on Dart Presentation:

Presentation Title : 

Introduction to Dart for server side development  ( 60 min  ) 

Description:

Dart is Google's new language for the modern web. With robust libraries and runtimes, you can build web apps as well as scalable backends.

In this presentation we will introduce you to Dart and the tools you need to start building powerful realtime backends to your web and mobile clients. 

We'll go over Dart language features that enable simplicity when building large codebases and lastly walk through various Dart frameworks that enable you to easily and quickly build REST and RPC backends.

About Faisal Abid:

Faisal Abid is an entrepreneur and engineer. He is a Google developer expert for Dart and a programming language enthusiast. Faisal loves solving software engineering challenges across the stack.

At any point in time you can find Faisal developing mobile applications either on iOS/Android, or writing backends in Dart.

events.name: Launching and growing a startup on the Google Cloud Platform
events.description:
Hello Everyone,

Hope you are enjoying the summer as much as we are!

We are extremely excited to announce that Jerome Mouton, a Google Developer Expert, is coming from Berlin, Germany to Toronto! He will be giving a short presentation on the Google Cloud platform and lead a discussion for all those wanting to dig deeper into the platform.

Please remember to RSVP before it's full!

Date:

Tuesday, August 4th

Time:

Meetup starts at 7 pm sharp.

Presentation Preview

Are you a developer with exciting ideas to launch online? Do you want to be all set for success from the start? This session will introduce you to the Google Cloud Platform through a replay of the past 5 years of SnapEngage's  engagement with the Cloud Platform.

We will add components of the platform one by one to watch it grow from an idea, to a feature and finally, to a SaaS (Software as a Service) serving billions of queries every month.

We will cover Google AppEngine, Google CloudStorage, Google BigQuery, Google Compute Engine and mention some interesting non-Google developer products that complement the Cloud Platform.

Agenda 
- 6:30 - Doors Open

- 7:00 - Intro

- 7:05 - Presentation by Jerome Mouton!

About the Presenter: Jerome Mouton is a Google Developer Expert for The Google Cloud Platform. Jerome is the co-founder and CTO at SnapEngage, a customer engagement and live chat solution. He is also a lead for GDG Berlin. Previously, he founded LjmSite, a developer of gadgets for the web, on the Google Gadget platforms such as iGoogle, Orkut and AdWords. He has been using the Google AppEngine Python since 2008, and AppEngine Java from early 2009.

events.name: September Meetup: Android Auto - The Right Information for the Road Ahead
events.description:
Hello Everyone,

Hope you are enjoying the last bit of summer.

We are very excited to have Phil Shadlyn from IDEAL LIFE as our speaker for the September meetup! He will be giving us a great exposure about Android Auto that was announced at Google I/O this year. You may find more details about the presentation below.

Please remember to RSVP before it's full!

Date:

Thursday, September 24th

Time:

Meetup starts at 6:30 pm sharp.

Presentation Preview

Curious about Android Auto?  Announced at Google I/O 2014, Android Auto is Google’s attempt to bring Android to the car, with controls and a user interface optimized for driving.  The first cars with Auto support were released this past summer, giving developers a unique opportunity to reach a new set of users with their apps.  The goal of this session is to get you started developing great apps for this emerging platform.

We’ll talk about how to:

Extend your existing audio or messaging app to be compatible with an Android Auto head unit;

Use Android Auto to play music, compose and read messages and respond to user voice actions;

Develop and test your apps with the new Desktop Head Unit;

Make sense of the Android Auto design guidelines and usability requirements that are in place for Auto apps;

Distribute your Auto app through Google Play.

Join us as we walk through real-life examples and see just how easy it is to get started with Android Auto!

Agenda 

- 6:00 - Doors Open

- 6:30 - Intro

- 6:35 - Presentation by Phil Shadlyn!

About the Presenter: 

I love Android even more than baseball.

I head up Android development for IDEAL LIFE, a leader in remote medical monitoring and mobile healthcare (www.ideallife.com).  I’ve also done Android development for Triplify, an Australian-based startup which tells you what’s going on wherever you are (www.triplify.com).  I’ve done time as an indie developer, and in a past life I worked as a controls engineer.  I started working with Android during the Froyo days and have never looked back.

events.name: November GDG Meetup - AndroidTO + Deep Dive into the Android Graphics Pipeline
events.description:
Hey Folks -

As a primer for AndroidTO we will be squeezing one last GDG Meetup in before the big show on December 1 -

We will be joined by one of the speakers at the upcoming conference doing a tech deep-dive case study:

Yervant Kulbashian, Senior Mobile Developer at BNOTIONS will use the Second Cup Rewards app as a case study, diving into the Android graphics pipeline, and explain how he and his team ultimately brought the liquid simulation to life.

Yervant will describe how Android uses Surfaces and image buffers behind the scenes, and go over some common pitfalls in rendering on Android.

In addition, Yervant will shed some light on some tips and tools to keep your Surfaces lightweight and fluid.

(This topic assumes high proficiency in Android and some familiarity with OpenGL graphics.)

In addition to the talk, we will also take a look at some of the latest news coming out of the Google Camp, and make sure we set the stage right for the AndroidTO Conference!

events.name: Fabulous Firebase Code Lab
events.description:
GDG Toronto Members!

Join us this coming Saturday for the first iteration of our Firebase Code Lab!

This will be a 4-hour guided workshop taking participants through getting a Firebase-based project up and running.

For those of you who may be unfamiliar, Firebase is a product designed to take care of the backend data-storage and authorization for you so you can focus on building your app.

Need user authentication? Got it.

Need data storage? Got it.

Need a backend that will service multiple apps or products? Got it.

You can find details on the Firebase website: https://firebase.google.com

Firebase can be used as a backend system across most popular modern platforms - whether you are building Web apps, Android apps, iOS apps, Firebase may be a viable option for you to look into.


Format and Topics

During this Code Lab, we will be going through an example where we will integrate Firebase into a web project.

Along the way, we will learn about

Using Firebase for 

• Authentication (ie account login)

• Data Storage

• User Access Control

Javascript Techniques

• Working with Promises

• Working with Callbacks

Location

Symbility Intersect HQ - 106 Front St. E. #200 near St. Lawrence Market


Who is this for?

We will be going through our Firebase project using HTML, CSS and Javascript, therefore *some* familiarity with these would be required. 

You do not need to necessarily be an expert, but you should have some awareness of Web development and what APIs do.


Requirements

• You need to bring a laptop

• You should set up a Firebase account

• You will need to install Node (https://nodejs.org/en/) on your laptop

*if you need help with any of these configuration items, please make it a point to show up 30 minutes early for the Code Lab


RSVP

There are a limited number of seats available, so please do not RSVP if you will be unable to attend.

Let us know if you have any questions in the comments below!

events.name: Progressive Web App Roadshow
events.description:
GDG Toronto Members -

Google is putting on a series of conferences across North America to bring the tools and techniques required to make incredible web experiences front and centre.

The Toronto stop is happening on Monday, September 19 at MaRS, and you can join in on the action by registering at the following link:

https://events.withgoogle.com/pwa-roadshow-north-america/

Here are details from the site, where you will also find the agenda and speakers who will be joining for the day.

****************

Welcome to our North American Progressive Web App Roadshow!

Progressive Web Apps are experiences that combine the best of the web and the best of apps. They load quickly, even on flaky networks, can re-engage with users by sending web push notifications, have an icon on the home screen and load as top-level, full screen experiences.

In this series of events, we'll explain the what, why and how of Progressive Web Apps, and work through some code labs to give you some hands-on experience (bring your laptop!)

Please join us to learn about the future of the web with Progressive Web Apps, why they are important and how to build and deploy them effectively.

********************

Please let us know if you have any questions, and we will try to get them sorted out for you -

Hope to see you at the event!

events.name: "Hack Your Life" - Intro to Hardware Hacking
events.description:
**NOTE: registration fee includes a complete Arduino kit! Details below**

Hey Folks!

Have you ever found yourself wondering what the big IoT (Internet of Things) craze is all about?

Are you excited about the prospect of hardware hacking, but don't know where to start?

Are you tired of Intro to Hardware-hacks that only show you how to light up an LED?

Are you confused between your DC's and AC's or accidentally tried to eat a bread board?

Here's your chance to figure it all out!

As a part of National Engineering Month (http://nemontario.ca/), the GDG Toronto team is hosting a Hardware Workshop and Hack event aimed at anybody who hasn't jumped on the hardware-hacking bandwagon.

This event will feature:

• an introduction to hardware development workshop during the morning (led by Macy Kuang, Google Developer Expert for IoT and Wearable Technologies)

• a catered lunch

• an afternoon of building and hacking on projects

The team has been working hard to make sure this event is beginner-friendly, but it will require some hardware and software tools.

If you don't have these available, don't worry!

We have a bunch of kits that we've put together specifically for this event.

These kits are available as part of the registration fee, for which you will receive everything you need to get started:

• Arduino UNO

• USB cable for Arduino

• a relay

• an H-Bridge

• a half-size breadboard

• lead wires

Aside from these tools that will be provided, Participants are required to bring their own laptop.

Participants are also required to install Arduino on their Laptop prior to the event.


Schedule

9:00am - Registration

9:30am - Workshop Begins

- Introduction to Sensors and Controllers hands-on workshop

- Learn how to build a circuit on a breadboard

10:30am - Break

11:00am - Control motors with Arduino

12:30pm - Lunch Served and Group Formation

1:30pm - Hacking on Projects

4:00pm - Show and Tell - Each team shows off what they made!

5:00pm - Closing

Mentors / Assistants

If you are experienced with Hardware development, and are interested in helping out at the event, please get in touch with the meetup organizers -

We would love to hear from you!

Any other thoughts, questions, or concerns, please let us know in the comments on Meetup -

Meetup details are subject to change.

Look forward to seeing you there!

events.name: 2 Talks 2 Start Your Summer
events.description:
Hello there, GDG-ers!

Guess what? Summer is almost here! And to celebrate, we’re bringing you some more talks to start your Summer off right!

We’re inviting you to GDG Toronto’s 2 Talks 2 Start Your Summer

GDG Toronto would like to welcome Michal Tajchert to Toronto for this session. Michal is joining us from GDG Warsawa in Poland and bringing us some Firebase tips and tricks.

Along with Michal, we’ll also be joined by Namrata Bandekar giving us a sneak-peek at her 360|AnDev talk.

Schedule:

6:30 — Doors Open

7:00-7:40 — Firebase: 4 Apps Later by Michal Tajchert - with Q and A

7:40-7:50 — Break

7:50- 8:30 —Video Processing on Android by Namrata - with Q and A

8:30-9:00 — Hang out, chat with the speakers.

The Talks:

1) Firebase: 4 Apps Later — What I Wish I Knew Before?

Pro tips and insights that I wish I knew before using Firebase. Going beyond SDK quirks and workarounds — even as far as pricing and how an app scales with 100k user-growth in a single week. Further topics being covered: Databases, Android SDK, Analytics, Crash logs, pricing, usage optimization and monitoring (external tools and data schema). And a brief introduction to new features including how to take advantage of them in the best way possible. If you are currently using Firebase, or you are about to, save yourself hours of pointless key smashing! 

About Michal Tajchert

Michal has been an Android developer for over 6 years, and is a Firebase heavy user. Michal has used Firebase in four mobile apps (from 1k users to 0.3m), won Google's award for best app in Europe with Firebase (Kanarek). He is the author of 12Hours, Pola, and the Kanarek apps. Currently, Michal is the CEO of Icelytics.io: a way to optimize and monitor performance of mobile apps. 

Michael is a follower of the Conjoined Triangles of Success, Serial entrepreneur and hackathon hacker; he’s always searching for new growth hacking opportunities and to share knowledge through mentorship and public speaking.

2) Video Processing on Android

Overlays, transcoding and cropping are just a few of the challenges you face when working with video on-device. In this talk I will go through my experience experimenting with built-in as well as third party libraries for video processing on Android. 

About Namrata Bandekar

Namrata is an iOS Engineer at OANDA and does native Android development as a side hustle. She is also a member of the Ray Wenderlich tutorial team.

Location

Symbility Intersect HQ - 106 Front St. E. #200 near St. Lawrence Market 

We look forward to seeing you there!

The GDG Toronto Team

events.name: Intro to Intro to Machine Learning with TensorFlow pt. 1 (not a typo)
events.description:
Here are the full details for the upcoming Intro / Workshop

## Agenda

• 6:30pm - doors open

• 7:00pm - Start time: Intro to Machine Learning - a Short Discussion

• 7:30pm - Building and Running a TensorFlow project

• a guided programming exercise and activity

• We will be focusing on a Machine Learning activity in Regression

• 8:45pm – Wrap-up and next steps

• 9:00pm – Good night!

## Experience Required

Attendees should:

• have some experience programming, and with general programming concepts

• have some experience running commands from Terminal or Command Prompt

For instance, in working with our Workshop Leads to prepare for this event, the following sentence was said: "We will be working with lots of arrays."

If that sentence does not worry you, you should be fine.

### **NOTE**

If you are excited about Machine Learning but have not had any experience with programming yet, please let somebody else make use of your RSVP for this workshop.

We will be putting together content for those of you who may be interested in developing core programming ability in the upcoming months!

## Hardware Required

Participants will require a Laptop.

Your choice of Operating System.

The installations listed here are what you will require on your machine for your Operating System:

https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r0.12/get_started/os_setup

### Specifically, note the requirements for

• Python (our recommendation is Python version 3.5)
• PIP
• TensorFlow
• install matplotlib - https://matplotlib.org/ (pip install matplotlib)
• install jupyter - http://jupyter.org/ (pip install jupyter)

Please come with these programs already installed on your machine in a way that you know you are able to run it

We will not have time to help people get their computers set up.

## The FAQ Section

### - How can I know for sure if I am ready to take this workshop?

• If you have some experience programming (not necessarily Python - maybe JavaScript, Ruby, PHP or any other language)

• If you feel confident in your ability to follow along with a coding exercise

• If you can follow this Get Started with TensorFlow reference:

https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r0.12/get_started/os_setup

All the way down to this step:

https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r0.12/get_started/os_setup#train_your_first_tensorflow_neural_net_model

Then you should be good to go for sure

### - I am not sure if I am going to make it to the workshop

Because there are so many people on the waiting list, please confirm your RSVP by Sunday night if possible.

Individuals who RSVP but do not attend the workshop will be blocked from RSVPing for future events.

### - These workshop requirements are new. I really wanted to learn about Machine Learning, but I do not have any programming experience. What can I do?

In this situation, we recommend you let somebody else make use of your RSVP for now.

We will be having events in the future to help people get ramped up to be able to take part in an event such as this!

### - I am going to be running late for the event. Can I still come?

No!

Please let somebody else from the RSVP list take your spot this time around

### - I really wanted to attend this workshop. I am on the waiting list, but I doubt I am going to make it on to the RSVP. Will you run this workshop again?

We had no idea there was this much interest in an event like this. If everything goes great, we will run it again!

---------

Let us know if you have any questions at all!

See you soon -

The GDG Toronto Team

events.name: Intro to Machine Learning pt. 2: Natural Language Processing
events.description:
Description

For the 2nd part of our Intro to Machine Learning with TensorFlow series, we will dive into more hands on exercises!

This time, we will look closely at Natural Language Processing with some learning and guided activities.

Roughly, we will be undertaking an activity to achieve the following:

Gather a dataset and process it into the desired format

create an algorithm and use the dataset to generate a model

use these to process new data and determine correlations

By the end of the session, everyone should walk out with a small AI project that will be able to do something like take a block of text and use the model developed to analyze the text passage for various criteria (ie. determine the sentiment of the passage, determine the topic of the passage, etc)

The goal is to get through a core activity and leave time for everybody to try out some things on their own - using different datasets or algorithms.

We are really excited for this event!

Please take a look at the prerequisite criteria and the required environments. We want to make sure that everybody who is able to join this event is well aligned to make the most of it.

events.name: Hack Your Life! - Intro to Robotics Workshop - 2018 Edition
events.description:
**NOTE: registration fee includes a complete Arduino kit! Details below**

Hey Everybody!

This year we are once again celebrating National Engineering Month ( http://nemontario.ca/ ) with a full-day Intro to Robotics and Hardware hacking event!

Last year we had an awesome event geared toward people with an interest in hardware, robotics and IoT - as a matter of fact, it was such a cool event that we are going to use the same format for this year’s event.

## Participants

Are you wondering if this will be the right event for you?

- Have you ever found yourself wondering what the big IoT (Internet of Things) craze is all about?

- Are you excited about the prospect of hardware hacking, but don't know where to start?

- Are you tired of Intro to Hardware-hacks that only show you how to light up an LED?

- Are you confused between your DC's and AC's or have you accidentally tried to eat a bread board?

If you answered ‘YES!’ to any of these questions, this may be the event for you!

## This event will feature

- an introduction to hardware development workshop during the morning (led by Macy Kuang, Google Developer Expert and Intel Innovator for IoT)

- a catered lunch

- an afternoon of building and hacking on projects

The team has been working hard to make sure this event is beginner-friendly, but it will require some hardware and software tools.

If you don't have these available, don't worry!

We have a bunch of kits that we've put together specifically for this event.

These kits are available as part of the registration fee, and will include everything you need to get started:

- Arduino UNO

- USB cable for Arduino

- a half-size breadboard

- lead wires

- Servo motor

- a 9V battery and a battery snap

Aside from these tools that will be provided, Participants are required to bring their own laptop and adapters for the USB ports.

Participants are also required to install Arduino (https://www.arduino.cc/en/main/software) on their Laptop prior to the event.

A mini screwdriver, a pair of scissors and other crafting tools and materials will be very helpful for your own project. We are going to use Cardboard and crafting sticks to create robots and machines.

## Schedule

9:00am - Registration

9:30am - Workshop Begins

- Introduction to Sensors and Controllers hands-on workshop

- Learn how to build a circuit on a breadboard

10:30am - Break

11:00am - Control motors with Arduino

11:30am - Sensors with Arduino

12:00pm - Demo of Intel Up2, Android Things and other IoT solutions

12:30pm - Lunch Served and Group Formation

1:30pm - Hacking on Projects

4:30pm - Show and Tell - Each team shows off what they made!

5:00pm - Closing

## Mentors / Assistants

If you are experienced with Hardware development, and are interested in helping out at the event, please get in touch with the meetup organizers -

We would love to hear from you!

Any other thoughts, questions, or concerns, please let us know in the comments on Meetup -

Meetup details are subject to change.

Look forward to seeing you there!

## Q&A

1. I don't have electrical hardware knowledge
Don't worry, that's what we are going to learn :)
2. Will ipad, tablets, Chromebooks, Android Phones work?
No
3. Will it work with USB C?
No, unless you bring your own USB cables or converters.
4. Having problems with Meetup.com?
You are not the only one, here is the Eventbrite link:
https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/hack-your-life-intro-to-robotics-workshop-2018-edition-tickets-43735449908

events.name: Google I/O Extended - Toronto 2018
events.description:
Hello GDG-ers!

It's I/O season once again and this year it will be coming to you live from Google I/O Extended Toronto 2018 at Devhub!

Date: May 8th, 2018

Time: Doors open at 12:30pm, Keynote begins at 1:00pm, TensorFlow Study Jam Kicks Off at 5:30pm

Location: Devhub - 46 Spadina Ave, Suite 400, Toronto, ON.

Timetable (time and schedule subject to change):

12:30pm - Doors Open

1:00pm - 5:00pm - Keynote live streamed.

5:00pm - 5:30pm - Dinner (provided), Networking, and Workshop set-up

5:30pm - 8:30pm - TensorFlow Crash Course Kick off

Details:

On Tuesday, May 8th, come join us at Devhub for Google I/O Extended Toronto 2018!

We’ll be streaming the Google I/O Keynote beginning at 1:00pm and kick off our upcoming TensorFlow Study Jam at 5:30pm. If you have wanted to get started in doing Machine Learning with TensorFlow, feel free to join us and be a part of the exciting upcoming Study Jam Series!

I/O Extended is being co-hosted and held at Devhub. They have a beautiful co-working space which they are opening up for attendees. This means that while we stream the keynote and subsequent sessions you’ll be able to work there for the day. This will give you the chance to both participate in Google I/O Extended and not lose out on a day of work.

Specific details are subject to change, as we continue to work at bringing you an outstanding I/O Extended experience.

About the TensorFlow Study Jam Kick Off: Following the Google IO Live Stream, we invite participants to stick around for the kick-off of our Machine Learning with TensorFlow Crash Course series.

Over the next 8 weeks, we invite participants to join us as we follow along with the Course materials provided by Google:

https://developers.google.com/machine-learning/crash-course/

During the kick-off, we will be going through a high level exploration of Machine Learning concepts, the technologies and tools involved, and going through some hands-on activities to help participants set targets for the 8-week series.

Even if the full Crash Course is too much of a commitment for you right now, this introductory session may still be of benefit if you have never had a chance to dig into what Machine Learning is all about.

Topics we will be covering during the session:

1. Machine Learning: beyond the buzzword

2. Understanding the problems that Machine Learning can and cannot solve

3. Where Machine Learning fits in our current world

4. Identifying a Machine Learning Problem

5. Technologies involved to get up and running with Machine Learning

- which programming languages do I need to know and why?

- how much Math do I really need to know?!

- how powerful of a Computer do I need access to?

6. Sources of data for Machine Learning activities

At the end of this session, participants will have:

- identified a Machine Learning problem to solve

- identified possible sources of data to solve their problem

- articulated potential success targets for their Machine Learning algorithm

We will also be taking a look at materials to review in advance of Machine Learning Crash Course session #2 (homework!!!!).

In upcoming weeks, we will be following along with the Machine Learning Crash Course on Wednesday evenings from 6:30 - 8:30pm through the end of June.

Look forward to seeing you there!

-The GDG Toronto Team and the folks at Devhub

Note: Unfortunately, the space at 46 Spadina Ave, Suite 400 is not wheelchair accessible. If you require any other accommodations, please reach out to us, and we’ll do what we can to help.

events.name: Flutter Study Jam: Build High-Quality Android and iOS Apps in Record Time
events.description:
As a part of the festivities in the lead-up to the AndroidTO DevFest (http://androidto.com) in November, the GDG Toronto Group is excited to present a Flutter Study Jam!

For those of you who may have not yet had opportunity to work with Flutter (https://flutter.io) yet, it is being touted as Google's Mobile SDK (Software Development Kit) with an aim of "Helping developers craft high-quality native experiences across mobile platforms in record time."

This Study Jam will be our chance to kick the tires on this framework and see if it delivers the goods!

## Study Jam Series Format
The Study Jam will be very similar in format to our recently completed TensorFlow series.

This series will consist of six (6) sessions that will follow closely along with the (free) Udacity course "Build Native Mobile Apps with Flutter".

https://www.udacity.com/course/build-native-mobile-apps-with-flutter--ud905

Participants will be expected to complete the relevant course materials in the lead-up to each scheduled session.

In-class sessions will be a hybrid of lecture (~30 minutes) and hands-on coding / development time (~90 minutes).
Lecture segments will cover:
- brief review of key concepts from the Udacity course
- supplemental materials related to app development
- supplemental materials related to releasing applications on to the various App Stores for distribution

## Tentative Schedule

Session 1 - August 29, 2018
- Welcome to the Workshop Series
- What is Flutter?
- Planning Projects to Build
- App Distribution
- Tips for Setting up the Development Environment

Session 2 - September 12, 2018
- Lesson 1, Chapters 1 - 13

Session 3 - September 19, 2018
- Lesson 1, Chapters 14 - 24

Session 4 - October 3, 2018
- Lesson 2, Chapters 1 - 13

Session 5 - October 10, 2018
- Lesson 2, Chapters 14 - 26

Session 6 - October 17, 2018
- Presentations, Celebrations and Next Steps

## Registration, Attending, and Participating

Registration for the first session will be open to the public.

Registration for the subsequent sessions will be done through an application process.

Similar to the TensorFlow series, this Study Jam will be open to individuals who are able to define an objective to complete by the end of the series, and who are committed to completing the full course.

The application form will be released in the lead-up to the first session.

Further details will be communicated as they emerge.

Hope to see you at the Study Jam!

The GDG Toronto Team

events.name: Flutter Study Jam Series - Session 1
events.description:

events.name: Augmented Reality with ARCore - Full Day DevFest Workshop
events.description:
Are you interested in building Augmented Reality (AR) apps but don't know where to start?

We are going to help you kick start your AR career with this full-day hands-on ARCore Unity workshop!

As a part of the continuing Google DevFest 2018 activities with GDG Toronto, we will be hosting the official ARCore Workshop at Symbility Intersect on Nov 24, 2018!

## About ARCore

ARCore is developed by Google and it works on IOS and Android. It provides native APIs for all of the essential AR features like motion tracking, environmental understanding, and light estimation. With these capabilities you can build entirely new AR experiences or enhance existing apps with AR features.

## Registration Details

There will be 40 seats available and the registration fee is $25 CAD.

The fee includes:
- A full day of learning and making Augmented Reality Apps
- Catered lunch, snacks and drinks
- The first 15 signups will receive a Google Cardboard

## Instructor

Macy Kuang is a Google Developer Expert for Wearables and IoT, and Intel Innovator for IoT and Gaming. She has been working as a game developer for over 10 years and has helped develop and release game titles such as Peppa Pig for iPad, Asphalt 6, Insidious 3 VR and more. These days, she helps businesses launch their creative ideas into interactive digital products at Miaomiao Games.

You can see Macy's previous talks online at: http://youtube.com/codetocreate

## Workshop Requirements

### Must have:

- A personal computer that can run Unity3D
- Download and install Unity[masked]f1 or later, download here:(https://store.unity.com/products/unity-personal?button=1)
- Download ARCore SDK for Unity(https://github.com/google-ar/arcore-unity-sdk/releases/download/v1.5.0/arcore-unity-sdk-v1.5.0.unitypackage)

Downloading and installing all of the software at the workshop will delay your progress, so we highly recommend you do so before arrival.

If you are interested in the event and have questions about the required programs or are having difficulty getting these installed, please let us know and we will see if we can arrange a time to help you out!

### Good to have:

- A Supported Android(Need to be able to install ARCore Android https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.google.ar.core&hl=en) and or IOS device and the cable that can connect your phone with your computer.
-- Supported list here: https://developers.google.com/ar/discover/supported-devices

- For Android Deployment
-- Android SDK 7.0 (API Level 24) or later(install it during Unity installation)

- For IOS Deployment
-- XCODE
-- A MAC
-- (Apple Developer Program is required to run apps on IOS.)

## Schedule
10:00 AM Doors opens, light breakfast
10:30 Welcome
10:45 ARCore overview and Deep-dive into some of the features
11 :15 Intro to Unity 3D
12:00 Catered lunch
13:00 Setup and configuration for Afternoon Activities
13:30 Developing in 3D - Poly Toolkit for Unity
14:30 Break
15:00 Build an AR app together
16:30 Showcase
17:00 Celebration and closing remarks

If you have any questions at all, please reach out and let us know!

Look forward to seeing you there!

The GDG Toronto Team

events.name: Google I/O Extended - Toronto 2019
events.description:
Hello GDG-ers!

Google I/O is just around the corner! We are excited that we will be hosting this year’s I/O Extended at Publicis Sapient.

Date: May 7th, 2019

Time: Doors open at 12:30pm, Keynote begins at 1:00pm, Google I/O Discussion Panel kicks off at 6:30 pm.

Location: Publicis Sapient - 134 Peter St, 12th floor, Toronto, ON M5V 2H2.

Timetable (time and schedule subject to change):
12:30pm - Doors Open
1:00pm - 5:00pm - Keynote live streamed.
5:00pm - 6:00pm - Dinner (provided), Networking, and Evening set-up
6:30pm - 8:30pm - Google I/O Discussion Panel

Panelists and Moderator:
- Patrick O'Rourke, Managing Editor, MobileSyrup, Panelist
- Tamara Stefanovic, Software Engineer, TWG, Panelist
- Jigar Brahmbhatt, Mobile Engineer, Intersect, Panelist
- Jodie Zhu, Machine Learning Engineer, Dessa, Panelist
- Steven Zimmerman, Senior Editor, XDA Developers, Panelist
- Mark Reale, GDG Organizer, Moderator

Details:

On Tuesday, May 7th, come join us at Publicis Sapient for Google I/O Extended Toronto 2019!

We’ll be streaming the Google I/O Keynote beginning at 1:00pm until 5:00pm.

From 6:30-8:00pm we will have a Google I/O Discussion Panel. This panel will feature a uniquely varied group of experienced individuals from some of the top tech companies in Toronto (lineup will be announced soon).

The panel moderator will ask questions and lead a discussion around the products and services announced by Google at I/O and how they may impact the industry. Questions will also be taken from the audience as we aim to have a lively, fun and interesting evening!

We look forward to seeing you there!

-The GDG Toronto Team and the folks at Publicis Sapient

events.name: Firebase Study Jam Series - Session 1
events.description:
Hello Everyone,

Hope all is well.

Starting on Monday, May 13, we are launching a Firebase Study Jam Series!
Monday, May 13th at 6:30pm.
Doors will open at 6:00pm.
Please be advised that we will be looking to to get started at 6:30pm sharp!

In this series, we will take a journey into Firebase and what its capabilities are.

Throughout the series, we will be looking at the following topics:

- How much did you know about Firebase?
- Why did you want to learn about Firebase?
- What did you expect to learn from the series?
- What was your app idea?
- What were some of the exciting accomplishments?
- What were some of the challenges?
- How did you resolve the challenges?
- What was the end result of the journey?
- What have you learned?
